Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 02:19AM puddingirl84 wrote: Julie_1958- I feel you're going to be just fine. And if it turns out that you aren't , then you have come to very good place again. A place filled with wonderful women who understand any and everything you might be going through. But let's stay positive for now. It's going to be benign again. It must have been very difficult watching your Mom battle BC for 16 years. I'm afraid my daughter is going to be a little nervous like you, because of my personal history with this disease. I wish I could take that fear from her. I hope this makes you feel a little better. Puddin'

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 03:44PM puddingirl84 wrote: First of all I would like  to say thank you. I am not Stage IV but I continue to get courage and motivation from reading your stories. I hope that's OK. You are the true warriors.  chainsawz- I have a huge family of women, sisters, cousins, aunts, a daughter. Not even a get well card or a phone call. Maybe they think BC is contagious. People can do some really cruel things. I think I am stronger for it.
Posts.Title: mean people stink..... chainsawz saint

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 12:07AM puddingirl84 wrote: Hi all- I guess I should have explained myself a little better when I started this topic. I wasn't wearing a mastectomy bra because I haven't been fitted for one yet. I was wearing one of my Warner bras with very light weight foam stuffing in the cups. And I put on one of my favorite tight fitting turtlenecks. I was looking good when I started out, but by the time I headed home some 6 hours later, my bra was under my chin almost! I had to laugh at myself.  I guess on these boards you really don't have to be embarassed about anything. The American Cancer Society has a publication titled, Mastectomy: A Patient Guide. On page 18 there is an illustration of a bra with suspenders attached to the panties. This is considered a temporary fix. This is a liitle too much of an effort for me! But I should have read the guide before my wardrobe malfunction.:) Puddin'

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 11:41PM puddingirl84 wrote: Hi all- I was at the the mall today roaming around in Nordstrom and Macy's. Every now and then I would catch a glimpse of myself in a mirror somewhere and say to myself, "oops!", give a little chuckle,then keep walking. I figure if anyone has a problem with it they don't have to look. I really don't have a problem being flat chested. I must be weird. Nordstrom doesn't have the selection I thought they would have, so I am going to the Wellness Boutique at a cancer center nearby. When I get ready. :) Blessings to you all. Puddin'

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 01:54AM puddingirl84 wrote: Twinkly- My journey seems to be almost identical to yours. I am scheduled tomorrow for bilateral SNB, then BMX on the 25th of this month. I have been DX'd three times (r,l,l). I said enough is enough, take them both. I really did want to wake up with breasts, but some of the techniques seem so barbaric to me. severing back muscles, dragging tunnels under the abdomen, pedicles. What compensates for the lost muscles, especially when I am middle-aged and starting to show signs of bone loss from the AI I am taking. Making that kind of decision so soon after a 3rd diagnosis  started causing me emotional distress. I chose to delay immediate recon and I want to make sure all the cancer is gone first. (I might have even posted this on another forum), but I am not sure how I will react when I see the scars. I will try and avoid looking at them for a while, but sooner or later I will come to realize that I am a breast cancer survivor, and this is my unique journey, my scars just becoming a part of it. If I am still NED at the end of this year, I will do a recon as a Xmas gift to myself. Also by then I will have loads of info from the several plastic surgeons I will consult with. I will make an educated decision about recon and not one based on fear of waking up without breasts. This site is truly a blessing. God Bless you for sharing in such detail.  Pudding
Posts.Title: Diary of a bilateral mastectomy twinkly pinkvictory

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 10:55PM - edited Mar 12, 2010 11:03PM by puddingirl84 Hi to all of you and thank you- I haven't visited the boards in a while. Doctors appts and such. Went to oncologist Monday the 8th. Onc told me chemo would start on the 25th. I think I am choosing weekly (carbo/taxol x12),because I am a diabetic and the steroids on the other regimen (carb/taxotere x6) were going to be stronger and make my glucose levels spike too high.  The last time I had chemo in 2007 (A/C X4), the steroids made my glucose levels go up as high as 300 or more at times. So I think that's why the decision was made to go weekly. Does that make sense? So it looks like carbo/taxol X12. Onc didn't mention 3 weeks on 1 week off x4. Should I ask onc about that? I have up till the morning of the 25th to change my mind regarding which regimen to do. Do you think there is a reason why I should? I have decided against the port-a-cath. It was supposed to be put in on the 16th. I love my scoop-neck tops. I just want a place on my torso that isn't scarred up. Is that silly? I am just done with cutting for now.  BTW- Why is taxol used weekly, and taxotere every three weeks? I guess that's a question for onc.  I loved all your replies.Looking forward to hearing from you.  Puddin'
Posts.Title: Anyone on Carboplatin and Taxotere? puddingirl84 puddingirl84

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2010 10:12PM - edited Mar 7, 2010 10:16PM by puddingirl84 arby- What is radiation recall? What parts of the body does it affect? How was this regimen challenging? 4 cycles or six? Did you have a mastectomy? Did you have a PET or CT/CAT scans? Puddin'
Posts.Title: Anyone on Carboplatin and Taxotere? puddingirl84 puddingirl84

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 11:22PM - edited Mar 16, 2010 06:45PM by puddingirl84 Hi all- I went to my internist today for a regular checkup. I asked her about the two regimens I have been offered, Carbo/taxol x12 weekly and Carbo/taxotere x6 every three weeks. I told her I was concerned about the Neulasta shots and my glucose levels spiking on the 6 cycle regimen. She yelled at me. She said, "you take take the regimen that is the best to kill that cancer! Let me worry about your glucose levels!" She told me not to choose the easy way out, and she gave me a script for Humalog, an insulin pen, to be used when and if my blood sugars go over 200. I won't need it after chemo is finished. She is sending me to the Diabetes Center to learn how to use it.  So on the 25th of this month I start chemo and I have to sign that agreement first as to which regimen I choose, I will ask my onc which one is the best? And that's what I'll sign. It will probably be Carboplatin and Taxotere.  What do you think?  Puddin'
